line_1: My Head, quoth Dick, to serve your Whim?
line_2: Spare That, and take some other Limb.

line_1: If he be silent, faith is all a whim,
line_2: Then Baal is the God and worship him.

line_1: The tale for wonder and the joke for whim,
line_2: The half-sung sermon and the half-groan'd hymn.

line_1: He had no party's rage, no sect'ry's whim:
line_2: Christian and countrymen was all with him:

line_1: Fame (now his friend), fear, novelty, and whim,
line_2: And fashion, sent the varying sex to him:

line_1: "It was his nature, but they thought it whim,
line_2: " And so our beaux and beauties turn'd from him:

line_1: And half of those have some peculiar whim
line_2: Their test of sense, and read but to condemn.

line_1: Monarchs of mode, and worshippers of whim.
line_2: Who lightly bounding o'er life's surface skim,

line_1: Wearing out life in his religious whim,
line_2: 'Till his religious whimsy wears out him.

line_1: Fill up the measure of the motley whim
line_2: With shrug, wink, snuffle, and convulsive limb;

line_1: He wrapt in Wisdom, and they whirl'd by Whim.
line_2: As careless he for them, as they for him;

line_1: We fancy 'tis a Whim:
line_2: They'd surely not have stir'd for him.

line_1: Bids her, indulging the poetic whim
line_2: In quaint-wrought Ode, or Sonnet pertly trim,

line_1: So very full of foppery, and whim;
line_2: What Creature's that, so very pert and prim;

line_1: The text that sorts not with his darling whim,
line_2: Though plain to others, is obscure to him.

line_1: Where's now the pliant Muscle big with Whim,
line_2: The various Voice, the oft-distorted Limb,

line_1: Whether I change thro' conscience, or thro' whim.
line_2: Just as I wear them; 'tis all one to him,

line_1: But, such was his unlucky whim,
line_2: It never wou'd agree with him.

line_1: Of delicacy full, and whim,
line_2: SHE, who on earth was nice and prim,

line_1: What spirits were his, what wit and what whim,
line_2: Now breaking a jest, and now breaking a limb;

line_1: Religious, if Religion holds in whim,
line_2: To talk with all, he let all talk with him,

line_1: That Subjects were but Slaves, and what was Whim
line_2: Or worse in common men, was Law in him;

line_1: Has been scribbling of nonsense, just out of a whim,
line_2: Some whimsical trollop most like, says Miss Prim,

line_1: But whether this was truth or whim,
line_2: He would not say; the doubt with him

line_1: Down this full flood of pleasure, business, whim,
line_2: Ye who confusedly sail in motley trim
